DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: SILVEIRA, R. P.;Silveira, Ricardo Peterson;PETERSON SILVEIRA, R.;PETERSON SILVEIRA, RICARDO;PETERSON SILVEIRA

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Doutor em Ciкncia do Exercнcio Fнsico e do Movimento Humano (Universitа degli Studi di Verona, Itбlia) e Ciкncias do Movimento Humano (Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Brasil), com doutorado sanduнche na Faculdade de Desporto da Universidade do Porto (bolsista PDSE CAPES), atuando no Laboratуrio de Biomecвnica do Porto (LABIOMEP). Formaзгo complementar na Universidade de Calgary (Canadб), atuando no Human Performance Laboratory e Canadian Sport Institute Calgary. Jб colaborou com treinadores e atletas de nнvel nacional e internacional (no Brasil, na Itбlia, no Canadб e em Portugal), com passagens pelos departamentos cientнficos do ADN Swim Project e do Minas Tкnis Clube. Atualmente й Professor Substituto no Departamento de Esportes da EEFFTO-UFMG e colaborador externo do Grupo de Pesquisa em Esportes Aquбticos da UFRGS (GPEA). Membro dos comitкs cientifico do XXIV Congress of the International Society of Biomechanics - ISB Brazil 2013 e do XVII Congresso Brasileiro de Biomecвnica - CBB 2017. Бreas de interesse: Biomecвnica do esporte e do exercнcio; mecвnica e energйtica da locomoзгo humana; nataзгo e atividades aquбticas; treinamento desportivo.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: PhD in Science of Physical Exercise and Human Movement (University of Verona, Italy) and Human Movement Sciences (Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil). Performed an internship period at hte University of Calgary (Canada), working in the Human Performance Laboratory and Canadian Sport Centre Calgary, running out experiments and biomechanical analysis with many canadian international level swimmers. Member of the Biomechanics and Kinesiology Research Group, Aquatic Sports Research Group and leader of the RP Sport Science. Has participaded in the preparation of national and international level swimmers and is currently member of the Sports Science Department of Minas Tкnis Clube. &#10;Granted by the Canadian government (The Emerging Leaders in the Americas Program) and the International Society of Biomechanics (The International Travel Grant).&#10;Member of the scientific committees of the XXIV Congress of the International Society of Biomechanics - ISB Brazil 2013, and the XVII Brazilian Congress of Biomechanics - CBB 2017.&#10;&#10;Main interests: Mechanics and energetics of human locomotion; swimming and aquatic sports; biomechanics of sports and exercise

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Efeitos do uso de nadadeiras sobre a coordenaзгo de nado e a freqькncia cardнaca no treino de nataзгo
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: O objetivo desse projeto й verificar os efeitos do uso de nadadeiras sobre a coordenaзгo do nado e sobre a freqькncia cardнaca. Mensurar a freqькncia cardнaca, нndice de coordenaзгo de nado, freqькncia de braзadas, distвncia percorrida e velocidade de nado em nadadores. Esses dados mensurados serгo comparados com a utilizaзгo de diferentes equipamentos: - sem a utilizaзгo de nadadeiras; - com a utilizaзгo de nadadeiras pequenas e - com a utilizaзгo de nadadeiras grandes. Comparar os resultados entre as diferentes situaзхes: sem nadadeiras, e com nadadeiras de diferentes tamanhos.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Forзa propusiva efetiva durante um palmateio de sustentaзгo - Um estudo de caso
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Propulsive effective force during a support scull - A case study

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Revista Mackenzie de Educaзгo Fнsica e Esporte (Online)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Abstract: &#10;&#10;The effective propulsive force analysis in each phase of sculling motion may help improving the technique of this movement. Thus, the purpose of this study was to describe the behavior of the effective propulsive force produced by support scull (in a vertical position with head above the water’s surface) in each phase of this movement. For this, one swimmer was asked to perform the sculling motion during seven seconds, while videogrammetry and dynamometry were used in order to measure kinematic and kinetic data, respectively. Three cycles of sculling motion were analyzed and each cycle was divided into four phases (in-sweep, transition phase from in-sweep to out-sweep, out-sweep and transition phase from out-sweep to in-sweep). Coefficients of variation showed a different variation of the effetive propulsive force between the phases of the sculling motion, however the value of the force was almost constant during the phases (around 9.5 N), since low standard deviation and coefficient of variance were found.
